channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Earthquake Kills Hundreds in Southwest China
item.description: Many people were missing and more than 1,800 were injured after an earthquake, with a reported magnitude of 6.5, hit Yunnan Province.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In Televised Confession, Guo Meimei Blames Vanity for Her Misdeeds
item.description: Guo Meimei, whose name has come to be inextricably linked with the Chinese public’s distrust of official charities, was shown on CCTV state television on Sunday night confessing to having fabricated her association with the Red Cross Society of China.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN

item.title: In Fatal Flash, Gaza Psychologist Switches Roles, Turning Into a Trauma Victim
item.description: When an Israeli airstrike demolished the family home of Hassan al-Zeyada last month, he joined the fellow residents he has spent decades counseling.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Lens Blog: Still Life With Soldier and Bullets
item.description: Hector Rene Membreno-Canales makes photographs that combine elements of classical art with military iconography.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID GONZALEZ

item.title: 100 Passengers Feared Dead After Ferry Capsizes in Bangladesh
item.description: The ferry, carrying about 200 passengers, was caught in bad weather when it sank while crossing a river.
item.dc:creator: By JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and HARI KUMAR
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Family members mourned missing relatives on Monday in Munshiganj, Bangladesh, where an overloaded ferry capsized in the Padma river.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chemical Company Apologizes After Deadly Explosions in Taiwan
item.description: The chairman of LCY Chemical Corporation said that he “solemnly apologized to society” after 28 people were killed and more than 300 were injured in blasts that the authorities said were caused by leaks from an underground pipeline carrying a flammable gas.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A damaged car was removed from the wreckage after the gas explosions in Kaohsiung last week.

item.title: Germany Blocks Delivery of Military Parts to Russia
item.description: Berlin has taken a step beyond European Union sanctions on Moscow by preventing a German defense firm from providing parts for a high-tech training center.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Israel Suspends Attack in Parts of Gaza, but Strike Kills Girl
item.description: Minutes after a partial cease-fire was to begin, the Israeli air force struck a refugee camp in Gaza City, killing an 8-year-old and wounding at least 29 others.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Palestinians search for victims in the rubble of a building, after the Israeli Air Force struck the Shati Refugee Camp in Gaza City on Monday.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Does Being Russian Mean Never Having to Say You’re Sorry?
item.description: The Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 disaster has divided Russians over how to relate to their homeland.
item.dc:creator: By MASHA GESSEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Corsica’s Separatist Retreat
item.description: In the end, the National Liberation Front had no choice but to abandon its armed resistance against the mainland.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLES LAMBROSCHINI

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Israel’s Colonialism Must End
item.description: Israel needs to clearly state what it intends to do after 47 years of occupation.
item.dc:creator: By ALI JARBAWI

item.title: Europe Prepares to Commemorate Centenary of World War I
item.description: With ceremonies in Britain, Belgium and elsewhere, monarchs, prime ministers and citizens are recalling the “war to end all wars.”
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Sees Surging Demand for Surrogate Mothers
item.description: Though illegal, surrogacy has increased in China thanks to couples waiting until their late 30s to have children, which makes it harder to conceive.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Amateur ‘Terrorist Hunters’ Offered Millions in Cash in Xinjiang
item.description: Faced with rising violence in Xinjiang, China is offering millions of dollars in rewards to people who “helped hunt suspected terrorists,” the state news media said.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: British Citizens Flee Tripoli on Ship as 25 Libyans Are Reportedly Killed in Fighting
item.description: The scenes of anxious foreigners fleeing by boat recalled the mayhem at the start of the Libyan uprising under Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in 2011.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and SULIMAN ALI ZWAY
item.media:description: Smoke filled the sky over Tripoli on Sunday after rockets fired by one of Libya’s militias struck a tank in the main fuel depot.

item.title: Disputes Threaten to Derail Audit of Afghanistan Vote
item.description: Three weeks after Secretary of State John Kerry brokered a deal to impose a monitored review of the presidential election runoff, the process came close to collapse over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: An election worker counted ballot papers from the Afghan presidential runoff vote. The audit faced new delays on Sunday.

item.title: Questions of Weapons and Warnings in Past Barrage on a Gaza Shelter
item.description: An examination of the strike Wednesday at a U.N. shelter in Gaza suggests that Israeli troops paid little heed to warnings to safeguard such sites and may have used heavy artillery not designed for precision use.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinian refugees at a United Nations school in Jabaliya that was turned into a shelter in mid-July. A succession of Israeli shells struck the school last Wednesday, leaving 21 people dead.

item.title: Separatist Cadre Hopes for a Reprise in Ukraine
item.description: The pro-Russian leadership in eastern Ukraine is pressing ahead with a sweeping goal of establishing a lasting government.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vladimir Antyufeyev in his office in eastern Ukraine. Last week he was declared the acting prime minister of the Donetsk People’s Republic.

item.title: Kiev Journal: A City Divided Over an Occupation Without End
item.description: To some, the barricades in Kiev are an essential reminder of the price Ukrainians paid in blood to protect their freedom, but others want them gone.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Independence Square in Kiev has become a living monument and is hallowed ground for many.

item.title: European Sanctions Force Russian Carrier to Suspend Flights
item.description: Dobrolet, a low-cost subsidiary of the Russian state carrier Aeroflot, announced that it would suspend all flights as a result of sanctions imposed on Russia by the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH and NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: To Evade Russians, Plane Crossed Into Sweden
item.description: An American reconnaissance plane crossed into Swedish air space last month as it sought to avoid being intercepted by Russian fighters, American military officials said.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Nepal Enthralled by Visit of India Premier, Who Hits ‘the Right Notes’
item.description: A fractious country, Nepal has been united in its embrace of Narendra Modi, the first Indian prime minister in 17 years to make a state visit here.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India after meeting with his counterpart, Sushil Koirala, in Katmandu, Nepal, on Sunday.

item.title: Rescue Hopes in Landslide Fade in Nepal
item.description: Rescuers have recovered eight bodies of the more than 150 people believed buried, as more rain threatened the continuing search efforts in Mankha.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Dan Washburn on ‘The Forbidden Game’
item.description: A book examines the broad effects golf has had on China, from the poor worker who becomes a golf pro to the farmer whose land is taken to build a new course.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Children receive golf lessons at an exclusive kindergarten in Beijing.

item.title: Fighters From Syria Kill 10 Lebanese Soldiers in Battle Over Border Town
item.description: Dozens more Lebanese soldiers were captured in an armed offensive by Islamist fighters, the country’s army chief said, in the most recent spillover from the civil war in neighboring Syria.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD
